awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: A New Mechanical Coupling Metric to Enable Effective Biped Locomotion Control
awd_abstract_narration:
Legged locomotion has evolved to provide the primary means of locomotion for land-based mammals, including humans. While highly-structured or artificial environments may lend themselves to alternative means, legged locomotion still provides the most effective way to traverse many locales. These include uneven natural terrains, human-designed environments featuring steps and staircases, and disaster rubble consisting of natural and/or human-made elements. Because they mimic the human structure, biped robots are of particular interest for operation in human-designed environments and performing human-assistive tasks alongside their human counterparts. Several decades of research efforts have sought to move biped robots out of laboratories and enable them to perform a wider range of practical tasks in real-world environments. A fundamental challenge that remains before this vision is fully realized, though, is how to enable robots to move in the very dynamic and efficient manner of humans while still maintaining the excellent stability that humans exhibit. Most modern biped robots either move relatively slowly and thus expend an excessive amount of energy or else move more rapidly and efficiently, but are too susceptible to falls caused by only minor disturbances. This project seeks to enable the development of biped robots that move more like humans, in terms of both efficiency and robustness. It formulates and applies a new, more general metric of dynamic robot control and stability that exploits the underlying mechanics of human-like locomotion, demonstrating its utility in laboratory robot experiments. The broader impact centers around encouraging K-12 students to pursue higher education in the STEM disciplines by highlighting engineering connections between robots and children¹s own primary means of locomotion -- walking.

This project seeks to formulate and experimentally validate a novel approach to biped locomotion control based on an analytical measure of the control authority over the unactuated degrees of freedom. Legged locomotion systems are inherently underactuated because there are no actuators at the points of contact between the feet and the ground. The approach in this project exhibits the four characteristics of a universal dynamic control authority metric that would enable the design of controllers to produce gaits that are both robust and efficient, characterized by 1) generality of application to a range of movements; 2) flexibility for use with a variety of mechanical designs; 3) consistency with the natural dynamics to yield energy efficient gaits; and 4) analyticity to enable systematic mechanical and control design. The basic approach is, at any state, to decompose system velocities into directions that are aligned with the inputs, termed the controlled velocities, and directions orthogonal (with respect to the kinetic energy metric) to the inputs, termed the orthogonal velocities. A computable measure of coupling between the controlled and orthogonal velocities quantifies the control authority of the system over the unactuated DOFs and is the basis for the new dynamic control metric. Configurations where there is complete decoupling between the controlled and orthogonal velocity directions are referred to as dynamic singularities. Strong coupling is advantageous for the system to have good disturbance rejection properties, while weak coupling is desirable for the system to have good disturbance isolation properties. Thus, the project examines how a thorough understanding of the nature of the disturbances can be used to exploit dynamic singularities in the control of dynamic biped gaits.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed new tools to improve the control of biped robot locomotion based on a fundamental understanding of the underlying mechanics. To reach their full potential to benefit society, biped robots need the ability to walk in a fully dynamic manner more like human beings do, thereby enabling faster and more efficient locomotion. This work demonstrated how quantifying the coupling between motions that a biped can’t directly control (rotating about the tip of the foot as in the initiation of a fall) and those that can be directly controlled (rotating the full leg forward about the hip) can lead to safer, more robust locomotion at useful speeds. Simulation work examined the different roles of the ankle and hip in robot walking when disturbances to the normal gait occurred and put the robot at risk of falling. The greater coupling associated with the ankle motivates inclusion of ankle actuators in biped robots and lower-limb prostheses. Still, robot gaits need to be designed differently to exploit the coupling associated with the ankle as compared to the hip. The results also show that differential use of the ankle and hip in robot walking control mimics the different roles of the ankle and hip in regulating upright posture of humans in quiet stance. Experiments with a five-link biped robot (having a body, two thighs, and two shanks) demonstrated that a flywheel added to the body instead of ankle actuation can be actuated during steady-state walking to reduce the energetic penalty of carrying its weight. Using insight similarly gleaned from studying the coupling dynamics, other experiments showed that an existing control strategy for walking, called hybrid zero dynamics-based control, can be enhanced to improve the same experimental biped’s ability to walk across uneven terrain when it can’t see upcoming changes in ground height. This approach approximates a provably optimal control strategy, transverse linearization feedback control, that is too computationally complex to be feasible on current biped robots of practical utility. It also works equally well for disturbances in the form of impacts that either accelerate the body forward (a push from behind) or decelerate the body backward (a push from the front). Simulation work extended these ideas to show that biped robot walking can be even more stable (robust to unexpected disturbances) with a simple switching rule that allows the robot to select the most appropriate gait from within an established library of gaits. Importantly, this switching rule is simple enough to be implemented in real time on practical bipeds. Finally, the tools for analyzing coupling in bipeds were extended to the more general case of planar robots having any number of links so that they could be useful in other applications beyond locomotion.

           As indicated in brief above, while this work directly addressed biped robot locomotion, the results are more broadly applicable to robotic systems in general and to lower-limb prostheses in particular. Because the concepts of coupling between different types of motion within a robot itself or a robot interfaced with the human (as in a powered prosthesis or exoskeleton) are general, the findings of this study apply equally well. Walking is also an excellent means of sharing with young people the importance of science, technology, engineering, and math within society because it’s something they all do themselves. This project supported the investigators’ leadership of a First Lego League team, twice annual presentations and robot demonstrations to middle school students exploring STEM, twice annual presentations to high school students evaluating engineering as a potential career choice, and regular laboratory tours and robot demonstrations for campus visitors across a wide range of age and backgrounds. Finally, the project supported the education of multiple graduate students and undergraduate researchers, as well as facilitated the enhancement of a number of courses taken by both undergraduates and graduate students.
